snippet: Enduring and tough, the female divers of Jeju Island have been a tradition for centuries. Most are over 60 now, and their numbers are declining fast.
headline__main: South Korea’s Sea Women

snippet: The Bruins pulled away in the second half to beat the Golden Hurricanes, who defeated U.C.L.A. in a stunner in the 1994 tournament.
headline__main: 20 Years Later, U.C.L.A. Knocks Off Tulsa

snippet: The Olympian Tim Jitloff won the giant slalom at the United States Alpine championships by more than one and a half seconds when the Sochi Games gold medalist Ted Ligety failed to finish.
headline__main: Ligety Loses U.S. Race

snippet: Fred Couples shot a six-under-par 66 to take a two-shot lead after the first round of the Mississippi Gulf Resort Classic at Fallen Oak in Saucier, Miss.
headline__main: Couples Takes Lead

snippet: The Oakland Raiders acquired quarterback Matt Schaub from the Houston Texans on Friday for an undisclosed draft pick.
headline__main: Raiders Acquire Schaub

snippet: Roger Federer earned the only break of the match in the opening game, lost just three points on his serve and beat Ivo Karlovic, 6-4, 7-6 (4), at the Sony Open in Key Biscayne, Fla.
headline__main: Federer Wins in Florida

snippet: Corrections appearing in print on March 22, 2014.
headline__main: Corrections: March 22, 2014

snippet: Television highlights.
headline__main: What’s On Saturday

snippet: The Wildcats fended off Kansas State and won the chance to end the Shockers’ so-far-undefeated season.
headline__main: Next Up for Kentucky: Wichita State

snippet: The Cyclones overwhelmed North Carolina Central but will be without Georges Niang, who led Iowa State with 24 points, for the rest of the tournament after he broke his foot.
headline__main: In Dominating Win, Iowa State Is Dealt a Blow: Niang Is Hurt

snippet: Virginia held off No. 16 Coastal Carolina, pulling away for a 70-59 victory Friday night that was a whole lot more nerve wracking than the final score.
headline__main: No. 1 Seed Virginia Survives Scare

snippet: Florida Coach Billy Donovan said he is “extremely happy” at Florida, and Louisville Coach Rick Pitino, when asked, said Donovan “would never coach the Knicks.”
headline__main: Coach Faces Renewed Questions About the N.B.A.

snippet: Bridget Kelly, a former deputy chief of staff to Mr. Christie, and Bill Stepien, his former campaign manager, are refusing to comply with a subpoena.
headline__main: Ex-Christie Aides Seek Immunity in Deal for Bridge Scandal Documents

snippet: A 3-pointer and free throw with 3.6 seconds left in regulation helped Stephen F. Austin overcome a late 10-point deficit and become the third No. 12 seed to win in this year’s Round of 64.
headline__main: Staggered by 4-Point Play, V.C.U. Is Sunk in Overtime

snippet: A 12-year-old girl was seriously injured on Friday when she fell about 35 feet down an elevator shaft at a Manhattan co-op.
headline__main: Fall Down SoHo Elevator Shaft Injures Girl

snippet: In naming Mitchell J. Silver, an urban planner with broad national experience, to lead the parks department, Mr. de Blasio said the agency would do more to “work for all our people.”
headline__main: New Parks Dept. Leader Shares de Blasio’s Goal of Addressing Inequities

snippet: At a meeting, opponents said the proposal would invite scores of cyclists’ cars scrambling for parking to their streets, unsettling a quiet neighborhood.
headline__main: Bridge’s Neighbors Fight Bike Path on Tappan Zee

snippet: Brook Lopez, the oft-injured center, could be a key cog in the Nets’ revamped style, which depends on ball movement and a fluid defense, General Manager Billy King said.
headline__main: Lopez Still in Plans; Nets Stay on Roll

snippet: The Knicks almost blew a big lead against the dreadful 76ers, who lost their 23rd game in a row.
headline__main: Knicks Survive Late Run by Sixers

snippet: The former Blue Jacket Rick Nash was cheered during a pregame tribute but was booed loudly after a scuffle with Columbus goalie Sergei Bobrovsky.
headline__main: Rangers Top Columbus in Nash’s Return

snippet: As chief economic adviser, Mr. Weidenbaum championed a wave of deregulation but quit after a year and a half, unhappy about White House budget-making.
headline__main: Murray L. Weidenbaum, Reagan Economist, Dies at 87

snippet: Brendan Ryan, unable to play because of back spasms, expects to start the season on the disabled list.
headline__main: Yankees’ Insurance Policy at Shortstop Has a Physical Problem of His Own

snippet: Paul Strauss is campaigning for re-election as one of the District of Columbia’s two “shadow” senators, and also pushing to have the district recognized as a state.
headline__main: A Senator on the Stump With a Frank Message: Give Me More Stature

snippet: James Michael McAdoo made a go-ahead free throw with 3.5 seconds left and a key rebound on the following play to help North Carolina to a narrow victory.
headline__main: North Carolina Edges Providence in Final Seconds

snippet: The Boston Early Music Festival presented a double bill of short operas by Marc-Antoine Charpentier at the Morgan Library & Museum.
headline__main: The Sorrows of Hades and the Glories of Spring

snippet: The American Classical Orchestra performed Handel rarities on Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall, including a semi-staged production of “Alceste.”
headline__main: Works Seldom Heard, From Haunting to Jubilant

snippet: Ian Spencer Bell brought his text-choreography performance “Elsewhere” to the Martha Graham Studio Theater this week.
headline__main: An Autobiography, Written in Bodies

snippet: A blending of musical styles that emerged in postwar New York is experiencing a revival, and will take the stage with a concert on Sunday at Town Hall in Manhattan.
headline__main: Decades Later, the Clave Beat Goes on for Latin Jazz and Jewish Musicians

snippet: North Korea test-fired 30 short-range rockets off its east coast on Saturday, the latest in a series of military actions condemned by South Korea.
headline__main: North Korea: Rockets Fired in a Test Land in the Sea

snippet: The Shockers were not pressed by Cal Poly, which has the worst record of any team in the tournament.
headline__main: Wichita State Is Still Unbeaten

snippet: Federal authorities are investigating whether the company failed to disclose in its landmark bankruptcy filing the defects that have now led to the recall of 1.6 million cars.
headline__main: G.M.’s Bankruptcy Drawn Into Defect Inquiry

snippet: Months after Fredrick Brennan had over $4,000 stolen and was stranded in his wheelchair in the snow, he has a new power wheelchair and acts of contrition from New York detectives.
headline__main: After Leaving Victim in the Cold, the Police Work to Make It Right

snippet: An long-foiled proposal for a national institution suddenly gains traction.
headline__main: A Women’s History Museum, at Last?

snippet: The Tigers got past their first tournament game, which has been a problem for them in recent years.
headline__main: Memphis Struggles Past George Washington

snippet: Every spring, it seems, a little-known team and a big personality emerge from the chaos of the N.C.A.A. tournament to capture national attention. This year, the first candidates are the Bison and their coach, Saul Phillips.
headline__main: North Dakota State Thinks Big, Has Fun, Earns Attention

snippet: Mass Mobs provide a welcome shot in the arm to dwindling congregations.
headline__main: Dying Churches, Revived in a Flash

snippet: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
headline__main: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 21, 2014

snippet: A five-judge panel says that the termination of two Brooklyn teachers, who a custodian said had been undressed in an empty classroom, was “shockingly disproportionate” to their “lapse in judgment.”
headline__main: Court Orders Rehiring of 2 Brooklyn Teachers in Misconduct Case

snippet: Bucking a trend on the PGA Tour this season, Adam Scott didn’t experience a major drop-off after his low score of 62 on Thursday, posting a four-under 68 in the second round Friday.
headline__main: Following Great Score With Good One, Scott Extends Lead

snippet: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s assault on free speech reached a self-defeating low this week.
headline__main: Turkey’s Move to Silence Twitter

snippet: The Zags won their sixth consecutive tournament-opening game with a choppy victory over Oklahoma State.
headline__main: Gonzaga Is Good Enough

snippet: Villanova Coach Jay Wright got his start in coaching as an assistant at the University of Rochester, traveling around the state to recruit players.
headline__main: Trip Upstate Takes Coach Back to Roots

snippet: The Players Championship is changing this year to a three-hole aggregate playoff. It becomes the only regular PGA Tour event to use a playoff format that is not sudden death.

snippet: The trainer Stephen Cheuk, owner of the sleek workout center S10 Training in TriBeCa, shares five different regimens to upgrade various areas of the body in time for the warm season.

snippet: Gareth Bale’s late gallop and goal sealed Real Madrid’s 19th Copa del Rey title in a 2-1 win over Barcelona in Valencia, Spain.

snippet: Players at Minnesota State, Mankato, refused to practice for their former coach, who was reinstated by an arbitrator.

snippet: The Duke sophomore Rodney Hood is entering the N.B.A. draft. Hood, who sat out last season after transferring from Mississippi State, averaged 16.1 points and 3.9 rebounds.

snippet: The moves in Poland and Estonia are part of a broader effort to strengthen NATO’s air, sea and land presence in the region in response to Russia’s military actions in and near Ukraine.

snippet: The State Court of Criminal Appeals denied a stay on Friday for two death row inmates, saying it did not have jurisdiction — even though the State Supreme Court says it does.
headline__main: Oklahoma: Courts Spar Over Inmates’ Suit

snippet: Some Topeka high school students and their parents said they would rather keep their graduation day just a family affair, and not include Michelle Obama.
headline__main: Kansas: First Lady’s Visit Draws Criticism

snippet: Water cutbacks for drought-stricken farmers and cities will be eased somewhat, due to recent rain and snow, officials announced Friday.

snippet: The Department of Defense has identified 2,302 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.

snippet: The murder trial of the double-amputee sprinter has highlighted the wide gap between celebrity justice and the treatment meted out to ordinary South Africans.

snippet: Bryant University in Rhode Island has told its graduating seniors not to take pictures of themselves with their cellphones when they come onstage for their diplomas next month.

snippet: Recent surveys by New York City’s health department found that nearly 60 percent of landlords had not complied with existing rules requiring annual inspections.

snippet: The viral disease known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome has reached Asia, according to reports from Malaysia and the Philippines.

snippet: A federal judge has rejected an effort by American Airlines to quickly cut off benefits for many of its retirees. American, which is in bankruptcy, wants retirees who wish to keep their benefits to pay all the cost.
headline__main: Effort by American Airlines to Cut Benefits Fails

snippet: A friendship between two ministers is being hailed as one of the most unexpected and intriguing developments in a bitter feud that has split the Episcopal Church in the decade since the denomination elected an openly gay bishop.

snippet: Newspaper industry revenue in the United States fell last year, as increases in circulation revenue were not high enough to make up for shrinking demand for print advertising, an industry trade group said on Friday.

snippet: The Fresh Air Fund camping program gave one Bronx boy the outdoor activities he couldn’t find in his neighborhood park. Readers can help others like him this summer.

snippet: Quotation of the day for Sunday, April 20, 2014.

snippet: In the last decade, California farmers have turned increasingly to high-value crops like berries and nuts, which are in great demand. But these crops generally take more water to grow, which is one factor in California’s drought.

snippet: FULTON--Maurice 1919-2014 It is with great sorrow that we mourn the passing of Maurice Fulton of Highland Park, IL and Boca Raton, Fla., formerly of Glencoe, IL. Fulton, past president and chairman of the board of the Fantus Company, died August 3...
headline__main: Paid Notice: Memorials  FULTON, MAURICE 1919, 2014 IT IS WITH GREAT SORROW THAT WE MOURN THE PASSING OF MAURICE FULTON OF HIGHLAND PARK, IL AND BOCA RATON, FLA., FORMERLY OF GLENCOE, IL. FULTON, PAST PRESIDENT AND CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD OF THE FANTUS COMPANY, DIED AUGUST 31ST IN HIGHLAND PARK, ILLINOIS, AT AGE 94. THE FANTUS COMPANY (PREVIOUSLY, THE FANTUS FACTORY LOCATING SERVICE) WAS THE OLDEST AND LARGEST CONSULTING FIRM DEDICATED TO FACTORY SITE SELECTION. THE FANTUS COMPANY EVOLVED FROM A THREE, PERSON BUSINESS STARTED BY FELIX FANTUS AND HIS TWO SONS, IN, LAW MAURICE FULTON AND LEONARD C. YASEEN OF NEW YORK, INTO THE PREMIER AUTHORITY ON PLANT LOCATION, PIONEERING RESEARCH IN ECONOMIC GEOGRAPHY. DURING HIS TENURE AT THE FANTUS COMPANY, FULTON WAS CONSULTANT TO GOVERNORS OF 11 STATES, AND TO THE WHITE HOUSE UNDER PRESIDENTS NIXON AND CARTER. THE COMPANY WAS SOLD TO DUNN & BRADSTREET, AND IS NOW A DIVISION OF DELOITTE & TOUCHE. FULTON LECTURED WIDELY, AUTHORED BOOKS AND ARTICLES, AND TAUGHT A COURSE ON INDUSTRIAL LOCATION AT HIS ALMA MATER, THE UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO. SON OF WILLIAM AND SADIE FEDOTIN, YOUNGER BROTHER OF THE LATE LIONEL, MAURICE FULTON WAS RAISED ON CHICAGO'S WEST SIDE. AT AGE 13, HE BEGAN WORKING AT MAILING SHOES FOR $2

snippet: AMES --Louis B. 98, died peacefully on November 3, 2014 in Tucson, AZ. Born Louis B. Schultz in St. Louis on August 9, 1916, he graduated from Clayton HS and Washington University. He began his career in broadcasting first with NBC's guest relatio...
headline__main: Paid Notice: Memorials  AMES, LOUIS B. 98, DIED PEACEFULLY ON NOVEMBER 3, 2014 IN TUCSON, AZ. BORN LOUIS B. SCHULTZ IN ST. LOUIS ON AUGUST 9, 1916, HE GRADUATED FROM CLAYTON HS AND WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY. HE BEGAN HIS CAREER IN BROADCASTING FIRST WITH NBC'S GUEST RELATIONS STAFF, AND THEN MOVED ON TO THEIR RADIO PROGRAMMING DEPT. WWII INTERRUPTED HIS CAREER. AS A NAVAL LIEUTENANT, LOU SPENT FOUR YEARS ON THE USS CORE IN BOTH ATLANTIC AND PACIFIC THEATERS. AS A MEMBER OF THE INTELLIGENCE DEPT., HE SERVED AS A " CODE BREAKER ". WHILE ON LEAVE IN NYC HE MARRIED THE STAGE ACTRESS JETTALINE PREMINGER. " JETTI " REMAINED HIS ADORING WIFE FOR SEVENTY, ONE YEARS. HER DEATH IN SEPTEMBER WAS A HUGE LOSS FOR LOU. RETURNING FROM WW 11, LOU CONTINUED UPON HIS DISTINGUISHED CAREER IN TV AND RADIO. THIS INCLUDED: PRODUCING LIVE OPERAS FOR NBC TELEVISION FOR WHICH FAMED COMPOSER CARLOS MENOTTI MENTORED HIM, CO, PRODUCING THE ORIGINAL " TODAY SHOW " WITH HOST DAVE GARROWAY (BARBARA WALTERS ASSISTED HIM) AND THE " HOME SHOW " WITH HOST HUGH DOWNS, SHARING AN EMMY FOR PBC'S " GREAT AMERICAN DREAM MACHINE ", PRODUCING " FIRING LINE" WITH WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY JR. AND FINALLY AS AN EXECUTIVE WITH TELEVISION INFORMATION OFFICE. HE LOVED PAINTING WATER COLORS AND PIANO PLAYING IN HIS GOLDEN YEARS. PRE, DECEASED BY SISTERS RUTH AND LOUISE, AND BELOVED WIFE JETTI , HIS SURVIVORS INCLUDE: SON'S TABOR (KATE) AND JONATHAN (JOANNE), NIECE ALISON (RICHARD), AND GRANDSON RYAN. DONATION MAY BE MADE TO THE THEATER WORKSHOP OF NANTUCKET OR THE INVISIBLE THEATER OF TUCSON. 1

snippet: HICKMAN--J. Kenneth. 86, of Summit, NJ passed away December 10, 2014. Graduated Regis High School (1946), Fordham University (1951). Korean War Veteran. Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Regis and Trustee Emeritus of Fordham. Served on Advisory...
headline__main: Paid Notice: Memorials  HICKMAN, J. KENNETH. 86, OF SUMMIT, NJ PASSED AWAY DECEMBER 10, 2014. GRADUATED REGIS HIGH SCHOOL (1946), FORDHAM UNIVERSITY (1951). KOREAN WAR VETERAN. CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF REGIS AND TRUSTEE EMERITUS OF FORDHAM. SERVED ON ADVISORY COMMITTEES AT RUTGERS GRADUATE SCHOOL OF BUSINESS AND SETON HALL UNIVERSITY. AFTER 37 YEARS WITH ARTHUR ANDERSEN, KEN RETIRED AS A SENIOR PARTNER HAVING OPENED THE NEWARK OFFICE AND SERVED AS DIRECTOR OF INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS PRACTICE IN NEW YORK. KEN SERVED ON NATIONAL FOREIGN TRADE COUNCIL, FOREIGN POLICY ASSOCIATION, BUSINESS COUNCIL FOR INTERNATIONAL UNDERSTANDING, IRELAND, US COUNCIL, AND US, USSR TRADE AND ECONOMIC COUNCIL. FOUNDER AND CHAIRMAN OF THE US INDUSTRY COORDINATING GROUP ON EUROPEAN UNION MATTERS, MEMBER OF AMERICAN COUNCIL ON GERMANY, NATIONAL COMMITTEE FOR US, CHINA RELATIONS, ECONOMIC CLUB OF NEW YORK, AND INDUSTRY ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO THE OFFICE OF THE US TRADE REPRESENTATIVE. MEMBER OF AMERICAN INSTITUTE OF CPAS AND NY AND NJ SOCIETIES OF CPAS. KEN HAD STRONG CONVICTIONS AND HELD EVERYONE TO THE HIGHEST STANDARDS, YET HE WAS HUMBLE AND ACCESSIBLE. QUICK, WITTED, HE WAS A WONDERFUL STORY TELLER. HE WAS A LOYAL, THOUGHTFUL AND EASY FRIEND, FREELY GIVING OF HIS TIME AND COUNSEL. KEN IS SURVIVED BY HIS WIFE IRENE (DAVIS), DAUGHTERS TRISH, CAROLYN AND BETH, FOUR GRANDDAUGHTERS AND A GREAT, GRANDSON. KEN IS ALSO SURVIVED BY HIS BROTHER WALLACE AND HIS FAMILY. SERVICES WILL BE HELD ON TUESDAY, DECEMBER 16TH, 10:45AM AT ST. TERESA OF AVILA CHURCH, 306 MORRIS AVE, SUMMIT, NJ. RELATIVES AND FRIENDS ARE INVITED TO VISIT ON MONDAY, DECEMBER 15, 2, 4PM AND 7, 9PM AT THE BRADLEY BROUGH & DANGLER FUNERAL HOME, 309 SPRINGFIELD AVE, SUMMIT, NJ. IN LIEU OF FLOWERS, THE FAMILY REQUESTS THAT MEMORIAL DONATIONS BE MADE TO ALZHEIMER'S ASSOCIATION OF AMERICA OR FORDHAM UNIVERSITY. FOR FURTHER INFO, PLEASE VISIT: BRADLEYFUNERALHOMES.COM 1

snippet: HICKMAN--J. Kenneth. 86, of Summit, NJ passed away December 10, 2014. Graduated Regis High School (1946), Fordham University (1951). Korean War Veteran. Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Regis and Trustee Emeritus of Fordham. Served on Advisory...
headline__main: Paid Notice: Memorials  HICKMAN, J. KENNETH. 86, OF SUMMIT, NJ PASSED AWAY DECEMBER 10, 2014. GRADUATED REGIS HIGH SCHOOL (1946), FORDHAM UNIVERSITY (1951). KOREAN WAR VETERAN. CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF REGIS AND TRUSTEE EMERITUS OF FORDHAM. SERVED ON ADVISORY COMMITTEES AT RUTGERS GRADUATE SCHOOL OF BUSINESS AND SETON HALL UNIVERSITY. AFTER 37 YEARS WITH ARTHUR ANDERSEN, KEN RETIRED AS A SENIOR PARTNER HAVING OPENED THE NEWARK OFFICE AND SERVED AS DIRECTOR OF INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS PRACTICE IN NEW YORK. KEN SERVED ON NATIONAL FOREIGN TRADE COUNCIL, FOREIGN POLICY ASSOCIATION, BUSINESS COUNCIL FOR INTERNATIONAL UNDERSTANDING, IRELAND, US COUNCIL, AND US, USSR TRADE AND ECONOMIC COUNCIL. FOUNDER AND CHAIRMAN OF THE US INDUSTRY COORDINATING GROUP ON EUROPEAN UNION MATTERS, MEMBER OF AMERICAN COUNCIL ON GERMANY, NATIONAL COMMITTEE FOR US, CHINA RELATIONS, ECONOMIC CLUB OF NEW YORK, AND INDUSTRY ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO THE OFFICE OF THE US TRADE REPRESENTATIVE. MEMBER OF AMERICAN INSTITUTE OF CPAS AND NY AND NJ SOCIETIES OF CPAS. KEN HAD STRONG CONVICTIONS AND HELD EVERYONE TO THE HIGHEST STANDARDS, YET HE WAS HUMBLE AND ACCESSIBLE. QUICK, WITTED, HE WAS A WONDERFUL STORY TELLER. HE WAS A LOYAL, THOUGHTFUL AND EASY FRIEND, FREELY GIVING OF HIS TIME AND COUNSEL. KEN IS SURVIVED BY HIS WIFE IRENE (DAVIS), DAUGHTERS TRISH, CAROLYN AND BETH, FOUR GRANDDAUGHTERS AND A GREAT, GRANDSON. KEN IS ALSO SURVIVED BY HIS BROTHER WALLACE AND HIS FAMILY. SERVICES WILL BE HELD ON TUESDAY, DECEMBER 16TH, 10:45AM AT ST. TERESA OF AVILA CHURCH, 306 MORRIS AVE, SUMMIT, NJ. RELATIVES AND FRIENDS ARE INVITED TO VISIT ON MONDAY, DECEMBER 15, 2, 4PM AND 7, 9PM AT THE BRADLEY BROUGH & DANGLER FUNERAL HOME, 309 SPRINGFIELD AVE, SUMMIT, NJ. IN LIEU OF FLOWERS, THE FAMILY REQUESTS THAT MEMORIAL DONATIONS BE MADE TO ALZHEIMER'S ASSOCIATION OF AMERICA OR FORDHAM UNIVERSITY. FOR FURTHER INFO, PLEASE VISIT: BRADLEYFUNERALHOMES.COM 1

snippet: BARNETT--Harold Walter George Of Pelham Manor, NY, died on December 15, 2014. He was 98. Mr. Barnett was born in Manhattan, NY, on August 13, 1916 and moved to New Rochelle, NY, at an early age. He was an only child. He graduated from Iona Grammar...
headline__main: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARNETT, HAROLD WALTER GEORGE OF PELHAM MANOR, NY, DIED ON DECEMBER 15, 2014. HE WAS 98. MR. BARNETT WAS BORN IN MANHATTAN, NY, ON AUGUST 13, 1916 AND MOVED TO NEW ROCHELLE, NY, AT AN EARLY AGE. HE WAS AN ONLY CHILD. HE GRADUATED FROM IONA GRAMMAR SCHOOL IN 1931 AND IONA PREPARATORY SCHOOL IN 1935. HE WAS A GRADUATE OF FORDHAM UNIVERSITY, BS, CLASS OF 1940. MR. BARNETT WAS COMMISSIONED AS AN OFFICER IN THE UNITED STATES NAVY IN 1941, SHORTLY BEFORE WORLD WAR II. HE WAS COMMISSIONED AS AN ENSIGN AND ACHIEVED THE RANK OF LIEUTENANT BY THE END OF HIS SERVICE IN 1945. HE WAS TRAVELING IN UNIFORM IN THE NEW YORK CITY SUBWAY SYSTEM WHEN WORD CAME OF THE PEARL HARBOR ATTACK AND PEOPLE CAME UP TO HIM IN THE SUBWAY CAR AND WISHED HIM WELL, THE FIRST WAY HE HEARD ABOUT THE START OF THE WAR. HE SERVED IN BOTH THE ATLANTIC AND PACIFIC THEATERS. HE WAS ON A PATROL CRAFT SHIP, PC 462, DOING CONVOY DUTY BETWEEN BRAZIL AND NORTH AFRICA AND WAS STATIONED AT VARIOUS TIMES IN BOSTON AND CAPE ANN IN MASSACHUSETTS; IN HOLLYWOOD, FL; AND IN PANAMA, BERMUDA AND CUBA. HE SERVED IN THE NAVAL INTELLIGENCE BRANCH IN SEATTLE, WA. HE WAS STATIONED FOR A SHORT TIME IN PEARL HARBOR, HI. LATER HE WAS ONBOARD A DESTROYER ESCORT, USS BRACKETT DE, 41, NEAR THE MARSHALL ISLANDS, THE MARIANA ISLANDS NEAR SAIPAN, TAROA ISLAND, AND AUSTRALIA. HE WAS THEN TRANSFERRED TO A MINE SWEEPER IN THE NORTH ATLANTIC RIGHT BEFORE THE WAR ENDED. AFTER THE WAR, MR. BARNETT WORKED AS A CHEMIST IN NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY FOR MORE THAN 30 YEARS WITH THE GREAT ATLANTIC AND PACIFIC TEA COMPANY IN MANHATTAN, MONTVALE, N.J. AND HORSEHEADS, NY. AFTER HE RETIRED FROM THE A&P IN 1982, HE DID CONSULTING WORK FOR CLAIROL CO. IN STAMFORD, CT. HE MARRIED MARY THERESA HARKINS OF BROOKLYN, NY, WHOM HE MET AT THE A&P, ON HIS BIRTHDAY IN 1949. THEY WERE MARRIED FOR 60 YEARS; SHE DIED ON SEPTEMBER 9, 2009. A CELEBRATION OF HAROLD'S LIFE WILL BE HELD AT THE PELHAM FUNERAL HOME, 64 LINCOLN AVENUE FROM 2PM TO 4PM AND 7PM TO 9PM ON THURSDAY, DECEMBER 18TH. THERE WILL BE A REQUIEM MASS ON FRIDAY, DECEMBER 19TH AT 10AM AT OUR LADY OF PERPETUAL HELP CHURCH IN PELHAM MANOR. INTERMENT WILL FOLLOW AT KENSICO CEMETERY. FOR MORE INFORMATION, OR TO WRITE A CONDOLENCE, PLEASE VISIT: PELHAMFUNERAL.COM 1

snippet: SILAS--C. J. "Pete." The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of our dear friend and colleague Pete Silas. Pete's legacy with the Clubs goes ...
headline__main: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILAS, C. J. "PETE." THE BOARD OF GOVERNORS, TRUSTEES, STAFF AND MEMBERS OF BOYS & GIRLS CLUBS OF AMERICA (BGCA) WISH TO EXPRESS THEIR PROFOUND SORROW OVER THE PASSING OF OUR DEAR FRIEND AND COLLEAGUE PETE SILAS. PETE'S LEGACY WITH THE CLUBS GOES BACK TO HIS BOYHOOD IN MIAMI, FL, WHERE HE WAS AN ACTIVE MEMBER OF THE BOYS' CLUB. HE NEVER STOPPED GIVING BACK THROUGHOUT THIS LIFE, SUPPORTING EDUCATION THROUGH THE PHILLIPS 66 SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM FOR CLUB MEMBERS, AND SERVING 30 YEARS ON THE BGCA BOARD OF GOVERNORS, INCLUDING TWO AS CHAIRMAN. HE BECAME A LIFE MEMBER IN 2000. PETE WAS AWARDED BGCA'S HIGHEST HONOR, THE HERBERT HOOVER HUMANITARIAN AWARD, AND WAS ONE OF THE FIRST INDUCTEES INTO BGCA'S NATIONAL ALUMNI HALL OF FAME. HE PLAYED A VITAL ROLE IN HELPING BGCA RELOCATE ITS NATIONAL HEADQUARTERS TO ATLANTA IN 1994. PETE'S PASSION FOR HELPING KIDS AND HIS GENEROUS SPIRIT WILL ALWAYS BE REMEMBERED BY ALL WHO HAD THE PRIVILEGE TO KNOW HIM. OUR HEARTFELT CONDOLENCES AND PRAYERS GO OUT TO HIS WIFE THEO AND THEIR CHILDREN AND FAMILY. BOYS & GIRLS CLUBS OF AMERICA RON GIDWITZ, CHAIRMAN JAMES CLARK, PRESIDENT 1
